tn.text: This word shows that the writer is beginning a new part of the story.
all the people on the earth (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: used one language and had the same words
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that all people spoke the same language. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"migrated" or "moved around"
Possible meanings are 1) "in the east" or 2) "from the east" or 3) "to the east." The preferred choice is "in the east" because Shinar is to the east of where scholars believe the ark came to rest.
stopped moving from one place to another and began to live at one location
If your language has a way of urging or commanding people to begin work, like the English "Come on!" you might use it here.
People make bricks out of clay and heat them in a very hot oven to make them hard and strong.
a thick, sticky, black liquid that comes up from the ground
This is a thick substance made of lime powder, clay, sand, and water used to make stones or bricks stick together.

tn.ref: let us make a name for ourselves
tn.text: "let us make our reputation great"
"reputation"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "we will separate from each other and live in different places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the people"

The information about where he came down from can be made explicit: "came down from heaven." This does not tell how he came down. Use a general word meaning "came down." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"to observe" or "to look more closely"

tn.ref: one people with the same language
tn.text: All the people were one big group and they all spoke the same language.

tn.ref: they are beginning to do this
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "they have begun to do this," meaning that they have begun to build the tower but it is not finished, or 2) "this is just the first thing they have done," meaning that in future they will do greater things.

tn.ref: nothing that they intend to do will be impossible for them
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "anything they intend to do will be possible for them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
If your language has a way of urging or commanding people to begin work, like the English "Come on!" you might use it here. See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:11:03|11:3]].

The word "us" is plural even though it refers to God. Some translate it as "let me go down" or "I will go down." If you do this, consider adding a footnote to say that the pronoun is plural. See the note on "Let us make" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:26|1:26]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])
This means that Yahweh would cause the people all over the earth to stop speaking the same language. AT: "mix up their language" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: so that they may not understand each other
tn.text: This was the purpose of confusing their language. AT: "so that they will not be able to understand what each other is saying" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"from the city"

tn.ref: its name was called Babel, because there Yahweh confused
tn.text: The name "Babel" sounds like the word that means "confused." Translators may want to add a footnote about this.

tn.ref: confused the language of the whole earth
tn.text: It means that Yahweh caused the people all over the earth to no longer speak the same language. AT: "mixed up the language of the whole earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The rest of this chapter lists the line of Shem's descendants down to Abram.

tn.ref: These were the descendants of Shem
tn.text: This sentence begins the list of Shem's descendants.
This is the flood from Noah's time when people had become so evil that God sent a worldwide flood to cover the earth.
"had his son Arpachshad" or "his son Arpachshad was born"
a man's name (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

Translators may write the words or the numerals "100," "2," and "500." (The ULB and the UDB have words if the number has only one or two words; they have numerals if the number has three or more words. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

We do not know the birth order of his sons.

tn.ref: Now these were the descendants of Terah
tn.text: This sentence introduces the account of Terah's descendants. Genesis 11:27-25:11 tells about Terah's descendants, particularly his son Abraham. AT: "This is the account of Terah's descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Haran died in the presence of his father Terah
tn.text: This means that Haran died while his father was still living. AT: "Haran died while his father, Terah, was with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"married wives"
This is a female name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This word is used to introduce new information about Sarai that will become important in later chapters.
This term describes a woman who is physically unable to conceive or bear a child. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
Here the word "his" refers to Terah.

tn.ref: Sarai his daughter-in-law, his son Abram's wife
tn.text: in-law, his son Abram's wife** - "his daughter-in-law Sarai, who was the wife of his son Abram"

These are two different names and they are spelled differently in Hebrew. One refers to a person and the other refers to a city. (The "h" sound in the city's name is louder than the "h" sound in the person's name.) You might choose to spell them differently in your language to show this.
